reviewText: If you want scary, play this. What is scarier than running around and fighting the hordes of hell or zomies, with a big gun? I'll tell you. Running around with no weapons and no way to fight back in a decrepit castle with monsters chasing you as you unravel a past so horrible your character drank a drink to forget it all. THAT is scary. Ok now seriously, this is a thrilling game. The atmosphere of the castle is awesome, getting darker and creepier the further you go. I'm not going to ruin the story, but lets just say you never see the twist coming. This game is literally a dark descent as you go from the main floor of a castle and travel deeper and lower into a nightmarish experience. Another dynamic is that you have to stay sane while making your poor character go through all this. From the makers of the Penumbra series (don't worry I'll review that soon, good game) this is a HUGE leap forward in terms of story and scares. As the people behind WatchMojo on Youtube say, Adult diapers are pretty much mandatory.""

So I'm not sure if I should recommend this game or not, but I will give one suggestion:  go into this thing with a strong stomach :)

reviewText: Truly one of the scariest games I've ever played. The atmosphere is tense and ominous from start to finish. I also found the exploration, resource management, and puzzle-solving to be genuinely satisfying. The insanity meter and monster evasion tactics necessary to survive make the game truly terrifying when trapped in a tight spot, though the monster variety and frequency of the main game I feel could have improved a bit. The addition of custom stories and smaller additional campaigns, however, solves this issue by adding a ton variety with numerous different scenarios to the to the mix. This is a must buy for any survival-horror fan.

reviewText: Frictional Games is known as a small indie developer that has had previous success in its survival-horror Penumbra franchise. Their most recent release, Amnesia: The Dark Descent, should rightfully remove that trilogy from the throne and replace it with Amnesia. The Dark Descent is an absolutely fanstastic addition to FG's catalogue given its immersive atmosphere into a truly terrifying setting. The sound, graphics and cryptic story are first rate easily leaving behind any A-list horror titles in the dust. If you enjoy an engrossing atmosphere with excellent gameplay and don't mind having to change your trousers every once in awhile then Amnesia is a MUST HAVE!

reviewText: At first i was kind of worried. Im so use to games jump scaring me into oblivion, which i feel is pretty cheap and annoying. reviewText:
After beating A Machine for Pigs I decided to move on to this game,and I can say that this game is as good as that game,if not better :)
The game centers around this man named Daniel who has a bit of a case of Amnesia(hence the title),and thwarts the plans of Alexander,one man who used to be his friend until Daniel found out about his real plans
For those that have seen a bit of gameplay/other reviews,you may know that this game has puzzles,and PLENTY of them.
I honestly have to say that my first time playing I just gave up when I got to the lab puzzle because of how bad I was at the game back then(xD),but after some pointers from my friend who completed the game before,and some prior knowledge from guides I saw and videos I saw I managed to beat the puzzles :),and overall the puzzles aren't too hard,so long as you know what you're doing
The atmosphere(which is typical in a horror game like this)is plentiful and actually managed to scare me in some parts,along with the monsters*looks at the water monsters*.
The music is good,not much else to say about the music.
The gameplay is great overall,kinda going with the puzzle stuff I mentioned earlier.
You also get this lantern that once you run low on oil with you of course need to refill it,there's certain cases where you actually don't want your lantern out otherwise a monster will spot you and chase you(and possibly kill you xD)

Overall this is a great horror game that I recommend to everyone for those that are looking for a really really good indie horror game,I guess my only complaint at all(and it's a small one)being the difficulty of some of the puzzles
9.5/10 from me :)

reviewText: Amnesia is easily one of the best horror games I have ever played. It does something that not a lot of horror games do, it will keep you scared throughout. reviewText: An excellent piece of digital-interactive artwork that uses the 4 essesntial elements of gaming (algorithm, player activity, interface, graphics) to spectacular degrees, all in order to deliver the scares and overwhelming creepiness of an experience that makes a game a true survival horror. The claustrophobic blackness of every step you take along with your character's (Daniel's) frequent gasps and whimpers over the incessant hauntings and attacks you endure throughout the campaign build a disarming immersion into a ghastly world all the advertisements and reviews of this game have promised. Although all your struggles charging through the game are inevitibly concluded with any one of the three rather disappointing endings, the sweat and shivers the whole shebang (quite effectively) offers makes it an experience totally worth a sappy resolution to forget about underneath the terrific fog of memories you'll make with the genuinely frightening gameplay and set pieces.

reviewText:
Don't let Amnesia's reputation fool you, this isn't just another jump-scary survival horror game! It has some of that, but the real scares are pretty varied and unpredictable, and the bulk of the game is actually progressed with puzzles. Overall I'd rate it a solid 4.5/5. There are a couple of puzzles that are pretty unintuitive, while others can feel a bit *too* easy, and the occasional encounters you're supposed to avoid being noticed by are more irritating than scary, but there's still a *lot* to recommend this game over others. The graphics are lovely, the audio and controls are immersive, a lot of the concepts and monsters are honestly unsettling, and the story is well-presented and enjoyable. Plus, even though there's basically no inherent replayability, the game is longer than you'd expect!

Quick Pro: Dark, immersive atmosphere.
Quick Con: Stealth gameplay segments are unsatisfying.

reviewText: Truly one of the scariest games I've ever played. The atmosphere is tense and ominous from start to finish. I also found the exploration, resource management, and puzzle-solving to be genuinely satisfying. The insanity meter and monster evasion tactics necessary to survive make the game truly terrifying when trapped in a tight spot, though the monster variety and frequency of the main game I feel could have improved a bit. The addition of custom stories and smaller additional campaigns, however, solves this issue by adding a ton variety with numerous different scenarios to the to the mix. This is a must buy for any survival-horror fan.

reviewText: This game is a modern horror classic. In addition to this, however, it is a very good adventure game. These two genres are blended together very well. Frictional Games has truly inspired game design. Many puzzles are clever and satisfying. This is one of the scariest games ever; sound and visual effects are implemented masterfully and instill undeniable dread in the player. That there is no combat further reinforces the player's vulnerability and encourages you to play intelligently to survive. Play it with friends for a fun time. If you like this game, check out Frictional's earlier games, the Penumbra series, which are games in much the same horror-adventure style.

reviewText: A great story that references real-world history and personalities and has mind-blowing twists and turns.  All while scaring the living @#%! out of you.  Be prepared for a grueling playthrough in most cases, depending on how lucky you get with the randomized monster encounters.  Best played either with a lot of friends in a room together if you want to sleep well, or alone at night with headphones if you're a masochist that's prepared to stay up all night clutching a shotgun.  If you haven't played this game yet, you need to get with the program and do it.\n\nFAIR WARNING:  I've seen things in this game that I almost wish I never had.   Squeamish players should not, I repeat SHOULD NOT read all of the books and notes inside the torture chambers.  Human beings are horrifying creatures, and the game references actual historical torture practices and devices.  While none of the acts are shown on-screen, all of the pre-recorded" sounds are there alongside the in-depth descriptions of what was done.  There's serious nightmare-fuel in there that's a lot more terrifying than any of the monsters.  Word to the wise."

reviewText:
I never played this game when it was being hyped, but i picked it up for free and it's actually a really good game.

The story was enough to keep me intrigued as it was slowly revealed to me through diary pages I found while exploring this enormous castle.  I think if this game didn't have the interesting story that it does I would never have finished it,  it's ultimately what kept me going.

The game was legitimately scary for awhile,  with monsters appearing in the darkest and scariest places of the castle,  and having to run and hide till they were out of sight.  There were even a few jump scares thrown in for good measure.  Although after awhile it stopped scaring me as I figured out how the monsters operated and found really simple ways to bypass them.

I highly recommend this game for anybody looking for a well thought out horror game,  I am glad I got it for free though because I can't justify the 22$ price tag for 7 hours of gameplay.

The story was enough to keep me intrigued as it was slowly revealed to me through diary pages I found while exploring this enormous castle.  I think if this game didn't have the interesting story that it does I would never have finished it,  it's ultimately what kept me going.

The game was legitimately scary for awhile,  with monsters appearing in the darkest and scariest places of the castle,  and having to run and hide till they were out of sight.  There were even a few jump scares thrown in for good measure.  Although after awhile it stopped scaring me as I figured out how the monsters operated and found really simple ways to bypass them.

I highly recommend this game for anybody looking for a well thought out horror game,  I am glad I got it for free though because I can't justify the 22$ price tag for 7 hours of gameplay.

reviewText:
I'll admit.... I'm barely five minutes in and I'm already creeped out.... This is... wow. I'm going to wait until I'm not alone to play more, I think!

****Later*****

Spouse came home at around nine in the evening. Played some more. Had both of us jumping at the slightest noise. Finally stopped for the evening when one of my cats started climbing all over me and purring in an attempt to calm/comfort me! This thing is freaky/spooky - a lot spookier than most of the games I've played!

We've agreed to play more of this... in daylight. And never, ever alone.

reviewText:
Amnesia the dark decent is a puzzle/ horror game where you must avoid monsters solve very challenging puzzles, and using the environment to your advantage as you try to remember who you are and achieve your goals.

Amnesia has a very good story line that is keeps you scared and interested through the whole game there are also many back story’s to explain what happened so long ago.

In this game you can only run or hide while in other horror games you can fight this one you cannot you must use your brain and wits to survive.

The Ai is very well done and it’s good at what it does I have not seen a single glitch in the game yet.

The physics are mostly perfect you can use the objects around you to make sounds to escape danger and also for barricading or solving complex puzzles.

The music suits the environment very well it can scare you at times and serves to help as well if used right.

What also makes this good is that it does not rely heavily on jump scares to cause you fear it makes you imagine there’s an enemy round the corner or in a certain location this means that your own imagination scares you and your brain is doing the work instead of none stop cheap jump scares.

Graphics wise this game is quite good, the style of it suits the game very well and the locations are well varied.

One of my grudges is that there is not much variety in monsters there is more than one but they could have made much more.

I personally got scared over and over again i love this game because it gives you a real sense of fear and no way to fight back unlike other games like dead space or resident evil where you could shoot the monster.

Its puzzles are varied and complex from the basics to finding a hidden item up to working out how to fix advanced machinery and other things.

SPOLIER ALERT

My last grudge is with the endings in which there are 3 one I agree with while the other 2 are nowhere near as good but that is just my opinion.

This is just my opinion but Overall amnesia the dark decent is a great game filled with horror and fright if you love horror then I definitely recommend you play this game and it’s not too pricey ever well worth the buy. I give it an 8.5 out of 10 I would rate it higher but there is a lack of monster types and the endings give this a lower score.

reviewText:
At launch Amnesia was, without a doubt, one of the scariest games out there. Nowadays there are a lot games that are as scary or scarier than Amnesia The Dark Descent.

Even though (or maybe because) Amnesia uses an older engine it creates a pretty eerie environment. Because you can't fight creatures and only uses a lantern (with limited light), the story and narration is pretty well done. The game is filled with weird sounds and torture devices, also your character will get scared if it's either too dark or ghouls are near. Because of this the game keeps you on edge the entire time

Really recommended for the horror lovers out there.

It's really good in what it does, which is making you feel hopelessly scared and powerless.
It's short but the main selling point is the unpredictability of what you have to do to move forward, so it's intense.
I really recommend it, it's very different from standard horror games

reviewText:
This is not usually my preferred style of game but that rarely matters when a game is good. And this game is good!

I don't scare or startle from games and this game was no different but it was still an extremely immersive experience. I had no idea what to expect going in and that actually added to the fun. The effects and simple yet smooth graphics are enough to pull you in visually. The sound is superb. And the gameplay brings it all together perfectly. Just a great atmosphere altogether. When enjoyed in the dark with a headset with no clue what you're doing this game can certainly get your heart racing.

You're stuck in an abandoned castle with nothing but a lantern with limited oil to burn and a few welcoming tips such as how the sanity system works and that the rare light sources in the game are your friend. The narrative unfolds through startled memories triggered by interactions with certain items, entering certain rooms, and notes found throughout the castle. The voice work is top notch and adds feeling to the story. Progression is made by doing some basic puzzles, exploring for items, and of course running away as fast as you can the second anything makes a noise or moves! There's a good sense of involvement finding the clues and making old machines work to progress to the next area.

Playing fairly cautiously I only died 3 or 4 times that I remember (one was scripted to advance the story) and finished the game quicker than I would have liked. I thought there were some clever puzzles but never anything overly challenging. Then I was quite disappointed in the anti-climatic ending, that while presented some ending options, did not present a challenge of any kind. I think this game could have used one last puzzle challenge to make it feel a little more rewarding.

But regardless of any minor negatives this was a fun little game that I got in a Humble Bundle somewhere along the line so it was absolutely worth it. Though I will say I was surprised to just look up and see a $19.99US regular price. Wait for a discount for sure, but do take it for a whirl.

reviewText:
Positive
+ Downright disturbing story, with notes obtainable throughout the game only further detailing gruesome details of events that have taken place
+ Great voice acting all-around (most notably Sam A. Mowry as Alexander)
+ The well-developed physics engine allows for some entertaining puzzles and interaction with the environment
+ Some good lighting effects help to punctuate the necessity of keeping out of the dark.


Negative
- Some poor gameplay mechanics: most notably the sanity system, which only sets out to hinder your progress rather than immerse you into the game; and even when I liberally used the lantern throughout the game, I was never close to running out of oil nor tinderboxes
- While the game does manage to retain a fearful atmosphere for the most part, in actuality there are only around 5 or so enemies that can actually harm/kill you, which makes the possibility of death inconsequential and reduces the overall ‘scariness’ of the game


Verdict
“Amnesia: The Dark Descent does manage to effectively replicate a scary atmosphere and tell a good story, which many gamers have recognised. However, the game would have been much better suited in another format (most notably a book), as it seems that--in its current form--it is more of an interactive story than an actual game. Nevertheless, the overwhelmingly unnerving experience alone is worth a playthrough.”

7/10 TJBs

reviewText:
Quick Summary – Amnesia is an “immersive horror” game with emphasis on creepy atmosphere and puzzle solving. Don’t go in expecting an action packed fight for survival. If you don’t enjoy running from enemies and sneaking around in the dark, you may want to look elsewhere.

You play a man named Daniel in the 1800’s who has chosen to erase his own memory, and wake up in an unfamiliar deserted castle, looking for a way out. Unfortunately, the only way out is to descend into the cursed innards of the castle as your sanity slowly drains away. As you progress, you find notes and diary pages detailing some of the events which have led to your current circumstances. The darkness is not your only enemy.

The game is played in first person perspective and while this is familiar to most gamers, keep in mind that you cannot fight enemies. All you can do is run and hide if you run into a monstrosity in the halls. To make matters worse you don’t just have limited health, you also have limited sanity, which is drained by witnessing disturbing events (objects moving on their own or unworldly environments) or by standing too long in the darkness. When you are unfortunate enough to run into a monster, don’t just run and hide, don’t even look at it. The more you look at a monster the more likely it is to become aware of your presence. Yeah, the monsters aren’t really roaming the halls chasing after intruders, but if they notice you, they’ll definitely squash you.

As mentioned before, a large part of the game is puzzle solving, such as trying to unlock new areas to advance by manipulating levers or mixing ingredients together in your limited inventory. If you’re used to games spelling out mission objectives or quests, you’re going to have a hard time.

Pros:
+Immersive game story with some genuinely tense and terrifying sequences (water monster…)
+Some challenging puzzles to get your brain working

Cons:
-The game can be frustrating since the solutions to a lot of the puzzles are not obvious, and you have the added pressure of working in the darkness under threat from monsters.

Overall, the game is not for everyone but if you like games such as Outlast, you should enjoy the horror element of Amnesia. Just bear in mind that the puzzle solving can be a real pain for first time players.

reviewText:
Reviewing horror classics this time.

The game, that changed the way, scary games were made... the father of Outlast !
What makes this scary?

1. The Atmosphere - The atmosphere is very tense. The game takes place in dark old castle, which appears empty (oh it is not :D). Authors made the sounds very frightening and whole game makes you feel like something is following you - you may just get very paranoid.
2. The Unknown - Why am i here? Who... or what is after me? WTF WAS THAT SOUND? thats the questions that will be very slowly answered.
3. Defenslessness - You just have no way to fight back, your only option is to hide. Enemies are uncommon in this game, which just makes their encounter surprising and scary and relies on your quick reaction.

Worth a try, but note, that this game is focused on story. Reading long notes is big part of the game - some takes you to flashback and some will hint you the solution to some puzzles, you will find along the way. There are no weapons, you will not be killing anyone in this game. They, however, may kill you :P.

8/10, you will never visit any castles ever again.

reviewText: Why am I writing this up? It's Amnesia. It's the game that everyone points to first when someone asks What's a scary game?" People that have never played it recommend it to people who will buy it and never play it. What am I even doing here?\n\nThe truth is
date: I needed a reason to revisit this one. I'm a terribly jumpy person and genuinely scary games can wear me out good. The first time I played Amnesia
recommended: I never even made it to a monster. I knew I needed to give it another go and this was the perfect time to do it. And while I was playing
hoursPlayed: a thought occurred to me. Amnesia's been around for years at this point. How does it hold up in a post-Alien: Isolation world?\n\nAmnesia casts you
voteText: unsurprisingly
helpfulPercent: as an amnesiac in a drafty old castle back in the 1800s. You soon find a missive from yourself
votesHelpful: assuring you that you didn't want those memories anyway and there's someone in the castle you really ought to kill. As you begin exploring the darkened
votesTotal: crumbling halls
votesFunny: you find that there are other residents of the castle that are none too pleased to see you. There's no fighting in this one
commentsCount: it's pure stealth or fleeing. The cornerstone of Amnesia's gameplay
column16: much like Penumbra before it
column17: is sanity. Looking at monsters
column19: and being in the dark make you lose sanity. Of course
column20: if you stand there in front of a torch
column21: the things that want to turn your insides into outsides will have an easy time spotting you. Encounters with monsters are all about balancing your stealthy skulking against your dwindling sanity
column22: which is only restored by progressing through the game. It's a finite resource system like food in Lone Survivor
column23: and works to layer urgency on top of your horror. I must admit it's a bit of a bother here though
column24: because it puts some irritating visual effects on you when it gets terribly low.\n\nThe sanity effects are about the only misstep in the aesthetics
column25: though. The graphics still hold up and manage to be rich and varied while still maintaining the dark
column26: oppressive atmosphere. The level design is simple but effective
column27: sending you through lavish halls and crumbling cellars and stranger places still
column28: pacing out the frights and creatures. The big standout here though is the sound design. There is a lot more going on here than in most games
column29: with your character making all sorts of breathing sounds and whimpers
column30: footsteps for everyone being accurate to the surface that produces them
column31: and even light sources making their own realistic ambient sounds. The castle itself is full of creepy sounds as well
column33: but that just makes it all the more effective when it DOES signal something.\n\nI was very pleased with the pacing of the game
column34: and found it had little to no contrivances to get you where it wanted you to be. Enemy encounters are infrequent enough to keep you on edge when they're not around
column35: and absolutely terrify you when they are. Dealing with them is obviously less involved than in Alien: Isolation but much more free-form than
column37: Outlast. I could see some of the terror being lost if you have to repeat certain sections a few times
column38: but the game is balanced well enough with pacing and items that it shouldn't be a concern unless you're really trying to pull back the curtain for yourself.\n\nTo my surprise
column39: I found myself getting scared more often with this than in Alien. For me
column40: Alien is much more about constant tension and the battle of wits with the xenomorph
column41: whereas Amnesia is more about the terror of being helpless and confused. Not many games have managed to pull off the powerless protagonist angle without it becoming grating
column42: but Amnesia owns it. Simple sounds and sudden visual effects will chill you to the bone
column43: not as cheap jump scares but as payoffs to the incredible atmosphere the game maintains at all times. I feel confident in saying that no matter how far the genre progresses
column44: Amnesia will always have a place of honor among the games that truly terrify."

reviewText: Amnesia: The Dark Descent is a Survival-Horror game, released in 2010. Gameplay involves solving puzzles, exploring, avoiding monsters and other obstacles. The game is in first-person perspective and with the lighting and soundtrack gives you a constant sense of foreboding. The plot is pretty intersting, though slow to unfold and the game has a Custom Story gamemode, which looks interesting. I played the original story mode and as the game suggested, I turned the lights down and put on a set of headphones, which enhanced the immersiveness in the game. There are DLC packs for this game, some of them are fan-made. Visually, while creepy it does look like a 5-year-old game, so if you are expecting state of the art graphics you will be disappointed, still it is well done and fun to play, worth the low price.

reviewText:
This is one of those interesting games... you're constantly being persued by a monster that you go insane if you look at.

Controls are a bit wonky and the game is 90% managing your lantern so you don't go insane sitting in the dark too long (this attracts the monster) with another 10% of the game solving puzzles. The story itself is deep and has a great deal of content that you didn't expect as well as some portions that can create different endings if you don't read what to do in the story.

Best to play alone in the darkness while holding onto a cat- that way when you screw up you can blame the cat even though she was asleep until you jumped scaring the crap out of her...

reviewText:
I'm one of those gamers that get scary games despite being terrified by them. Some horror games (i.e. Five Nights at Freddy's and Resident Evil) I can play because I've learned how to handle the jumpscares and the horror aspects.

...That's not the case here...

The atmosphere and the ambient noises are what really set the horror" mood for this game. Hearing footsteps from above is spine-chilling and the sound of your own heart racing brings the horror to life. The sudden noises will stop you dead in your tracks. Every room is another suprise and shock waiting to appear.

Multiple times I've stopped playing because I'm terrified of what's in the next room.

This game can burn out your fear meter until you just stare blankly at your screen

reviewText: Anyone learning how to make games should play Amnesia the Dark Descent. I say this because I can't really think of many other games that are so masterfully atmospheric. Yes the game is scary, hur da dur everyone knows that. What I love so much about Dark Descent is that its scares are not just cheap jump scares and sensationalist set pieces. It is intelligent in how it goes about scaring you, resorting to audio and a dynamic between light and dark to really bring you in. Amnesia will make you feel terror in a very raw sense that few other games can come close to. Amnesia is a hallmark of the horror genre and arguable a hallmark of video games alltogether.

reviewText:
I rate this game #1 constipation reliever. The whole dark atmosphere and the fact that there is always something lurking around the corner is very paranoia inducing. There is also the fact that there is absolutely NO way to defend yourself; running away and hiding is the only key to survival. Keeping your sanity, as well as your health, is a big factor in gameplay. Your character suffers from nyctophobia (the fear of darkness) which, as a result, causes your character to go insane when staying in the darkness for a prolonged amount of time. This sets a new difficulty for playing the game as you are easier to detect and movement becomes much harder while in this state. However, staying in light sources will make it easier for them to find you...


I HIGHLY recommend this game to anyone looking for a thrill, alone or with friends. I also suggest playing in darkness with a headset on for maximum effects. This game is NOT for the faint of heart; do not play with winning as your goal.

reviewText:
This game is a buggy peice of ♥♥♥♥, which randomly crashes upon switching maps, It's easy to randomly clip out of bounds (I managed to on my first playthrough) and items can often get stuck or go through walls. These are just some of the numerous bugs and glitches found in this game.

The options menu is kinda good and it runs decent on bad computers. But one problem is that the gamma settings are for the entire system which means that if you have 2 monitors and put the gamma on the highest setting, the other monitor will look terrible.

But the bugs aside this is about the best survival horror game you can find as I'm typing this. The first person view and making you not be able to fight back make this game really tense and scary if you are in a situation where the monster spots you and you must run. The environment, ambience and of course the soundtrack is mostly what makes the game scary. It's not actually the monster itself that is so scary, it's the premonition of him being around every corner you see that makes the game scary.

Overall i would recommend this game to people that liked Outlast because of the similarities and also to people that just enjoy being scared.

reviewText: This is the horror game you are looking for. Play this with headphones alone at night and you will experience a fear no other games or movies can give you. At the most intense moments, it's hard not to quit the game and leave the room in utter fear. You can't simply fight the monsters and ghosts in this game, so you will have to be careful not being spotted or not to make too much sound, or esle they'll come after you... and if they do, you need to run as fast as possible, while under the constant pressure of not going insane. If you are the kind of person looking for the scariest of games, this is the game for you. With a long, dark main story and a million DLC packs and user-created levels, the gameplay only ends when you're hiding under your bed, after smashing your PC in utter terror and fear.

since the main character ironically enough suffers from Nyctophobia (severe fear of the dark).

In late August 1839
column39: awakens in the dark halls of the Prussian Brennenburg Castle with little to no memory about himself or his past.\nAll he can remember is his name
column40: that he lives in Mayfair and that something is hunting him. Shortly after awakening

before he succumbs to either the monstrosities or his own damaged mind...

reviewText: When a game has the power to evoke an emotional reaction, other than frustrion and dissapointment, then said game deserves to be considered a success and that is just the case with Amnesia as it's hauntingly gothic dungeons, goulish enemies and bone-chillingly primordial sound design work to instill a sense fear and helplesness. Set in the 19th century Amnesia finds you journeying into the darkest recesses of a medieval castle without the aid of a firearm and punishes your character's very mind, making it difficult to navigate, if you stray a little too far from the light.

reviewText:
This game is a true masterpiece. Disturbing, mind-blowingly scary and more intense than your granny on drugs and skates.

Take control of, and see through the eyes of Daniel, an English archeologist who suddenly finds himself trapped inside the huge, dark and seemingly haunted castle of Brennenburg. Waking up, remembering nothing about his former self, Daniel emerges out on an adventure he won't soon forget...

You'll wish you never bought the game, yet you will get scared, and you will like it. You'll be completely glued to the screen for hours, trying to find the correct path, or the right set of rods for that damned broken elevator. Monsters will be chasing you, and all you have to defend" yourself with is a lamp
date: with barely enough oil to get you through sticky situations. The darkness will swallow you
recommended: and your sanity will be tested both inside and outside the game.\n\nIn conclusion
voteText: and you'll ♥♥♥♥ 'em hard! Totally worth the low sum of 30 bucks."

reviewText:
This is an amazing horror game that builds up tension like Slender, has jump scares like Outlast, and an amazing story line such as The Last of Us. The game is actually based off of true legends of Castle Brennenburg in Poland, the setting of the game. Amnesia is deep, and has recently been labeled as one of the top horror games ever made.
The environment in this game is very fitting, and you can manipulate objects to your advantage. The monsters are creative and unique and the ambience is unbeatable. As you walk through castle Brennenburg, you can automatically tell that this was perfect for a horror story.
This game is not straight forward all of the time though. There are puzzles designed to challenge the player, while panicking in fear of the next monster. Each part of the game can be taken at the gamer's own pace, depending on if you are a cautious player, or the run-in-head-first player.
Another thing that is great about this game is that it does not shove plot into your face. You can choose to pick up the notes that are scattered around the castle, or ignore them to complete the game. There are bits though, that are crucial to the end of the game that are forced upon you. There is a total of two cut scenes, at the beginning and the end of the game; that is if you do not count the times you regain your memory. These are short, although quite frankly annoying and tedious.
The game in itself has removed most of the problems, but can get glitchy at some points. Occasionally, one of the monsters will get stuck in a wall or you will have troubles with some of the items, but are easy to ignore. Over all this game is perfect for any horror gamer, but should be avoided if you do not enjoy puzzles. The ending is not one you should miss, and will bring you about 10 hours of nerve-wracking gametime.

reviewText: Anyone learning how to make games should play Amnesia the Dark Descent. I say this because I can't really think of many other games that are so masterfully atmospheric. reviewText: This is by far the scariest game I've ever played. The atmosphere in this game is amazing, from the castle setting to the superb audio and the constant fear of what you'll see around the next corner. I made sure to play this game mainly after dark with headphones and I am glad I did. It took me something like a year of on and off playing to finish the game, as playing the game  was mentally unsettling at times and difficult to garner the willpower to keep playing. That's OK though because that is exactly what I want from a horror game. There were many times when I squealed out loud in terror and even developed a bit of a sweat. I highly recommend this game and recommend playing at night with headphones for an optimal experience. This game makes me truely concerned of how horror games in VR are going to affect people. Good luck.

reviewText:
Puts the survival aspect back into the Horror genre and does a damn good job at it too. Hiding for the sake of your life and sanity is the playstyle here during enemy encounters instead of shootin' 'em up like a bad motha*****.  You're  goin' get terrified, and your heart's goin' race at times...no exceptions. I thought the developers were sadistic with the way they were toying with my expectations and making me feel paranoid nearly the entire game...truth is, they're just competent.

The only downside to this game were the puzzles. For a survival horror game, the puzzles were pretty weak in the sense that they were fairly easy to figure out instead offering a good intellectual challenge. There was also nothing disturbing or terrifying about them. Thus, I found that the puzzles were interrupting the flow of the game. Examples of great puzzles done in horror games can be found in Silent Hill. You had to decipher hard, disturbing riddles written in blood for example. Compare that to tinkering with levers and engines in Amnesia. Yeah...

The story while not great, is servicable. It's fed to you in bits as you pick up notes and as the protaganist experiences flashbacks.  You also have multiple endings here as typical in survival horror games and, again, they're servicable but don't leave an impact on you after it's all over. At least it didn't for me.

Fortunately, the good by far outweighs the bad in Amnesia. When you play, follow the game's advice and concentrate on immersing yourself within the atmosphere because that is the main selling point of the game.

I recommend this game to survival horror fans and gamers who want a thrilling, terrifying experience that doesn't rely on predictable, cheesy jump scares.

reviewText:
I rate this game #1 constipation reliever. The whole dark atmosphere and the fact that there is always something lurking around the corner is very paranoia inducing. There is also the fact that there is absolutely NO way to defend yourself; running away and hiding is the only key to survival. Keeping your sanity, as well as your health, is a big factor in gameplay. Your character suffers from nyctophobia (the fear of darkness) which, as a result, causes your character to go insane when staying in the darkness for a prolonged amount of time. This sets a new difficulty for playing the game as you are easier to detect and movement becomes much harder while in this state. However, staying in light sources will make it easier for them to find you...


I HIGHLY recommend this game to anyone looking for a thrill, alone or with friends. I also suggest playing in darkness with a headset on for maximum effects. This game is NOT for the faint of heart; do not play with winning as your goal.

reviewText:
This game is a true masterpiece. Disturbing, mind-blowingly scary and more intense than your granny on drugs and skates.

Take control of, and see through the eyes of Daniel, an English archeologist who suddenly finds himself trapped inside the huge, dark and seemingly haunted castle of Brennenburg. Waking up, remembering nothing about his former self, Daniel emerges out on an adventure he won't soon forget...

You'll wish you never bought the game, yet you will get scared, and you will like it. You'll be completely glued to the screen for hours, trying to find the correct path, or the right set of rods for that damned broken elevator. Monsters will be chasing you, and all you have to defend" yourself with is a lamp
date: with barely enough oil to get you through sticky situations. The darkness will swallow you

reviewText: A fascinating little game.  At its absolute best, it delivers an exceedingly unsettling experience; at some point, you'll almost certainly find yourself cowering in a dark corner hoping desperately that something doesn't kill you and balancing the warm comfort of a candle against the risk something will come around the corner and rip your face off.  At its worst, it's a slow puzzler with sometimes-illogical requirements.\n\nStill, as a short, play-it-in-two-solid-sittings game, it's hard to top the  feel it delivers.  Well worth the 6-8 hours it'll take to finish.

reviewText: Prepare your enviroment as the game instructs, and you'll get the full effect (as this game doesn't rely just on scare jumps). The story is good, and as you advance the in the game, you'll discover more and more about your character (making all even more disturbing). And it's almost cinematic free, with the exposition being given mostly in text and voices in your head representing your memories (or even something else). It has no combat, and all gameplay is focused in exploration, puzzle solving, stealth and running. However the sanity mechanic makes all this complex enough so it doesn't become boring (and you still can be injured or even killed by the enviroment or the enemies).

reviewText:
Title:
Amnesia: The Dark Descent"

Developer(s)/producer(s):
Frictional Games
THQ (retail)

Writer(s):
Mikael Hedberg

Genre(s):
Horror
date:
Survival

Mode(s):
Single-player

General info:
The game was critically well received
recommended: earning two awards from the Independent Games Festival and numerous positive reviews.\nOriginally released independently as a download
hoursPlayed: the game has since been published in retail by 1C Company in Russia and Eastern Europe as well as THQ in North America. A collection of five short stories set in the world of Amnesia
voteText: written by Mikael Hedberg and illustrated by the game's concept artists
helpfulPercent: was also made available.\nIn addition
votesHelpful:
the game's soundtrack is available for purchase and a free content expansion called "Justine" has been released as well as many fan-made expansions and stories.

Gameplay:
In a similar vein to the developer's previous games
votesTotal: Amnesia is an adventure game played from a first-person perspective. The game retains the physical object interaction used in the Penumbra series
votesFunny: allowing for physics-based puzzles and interactions such as opening doors and fixing machinery.\nFew in-game objects are operated by toggle; to open a door
column16: the player must hold down a mouse button and then push (or pull) the mouse. This gives the player stealth
column17: allowing them to peek out a barely-opened door or open it slowly to sneak away
column18: but also adds to the player's sense of helplessness
column19: as it is now entirely possible to attempt to push open a "pull" door whilst danger approaches from behind.\nIn addition to a health indicator
column20: the player's sanity must be managed.\nBeing in darkness too long
column22: or staring at monsters will reduce their sanity
column23: causing visual and auditory hallucinations and drawing the attention of monsters. Light sources help restore sanity
column24: and if none are available the player may use tinderboxes to ignite candles in wall sconces and candelabra
column25: or deploy an oil-burning lantern found near the beginning of the game.\nHowever
column26: the number of tinderboxes and the amount of oil available are both limited
column27: and standing in a light source also makes the player more noticeable to monsters. The player must balance the amount of time they spends in light and shadow. Sanity is fully restored once the player completes an objective or progresses the game's story.\n\nIf a monster spots the player
column28: it will chase it until it's out of sight. If spotted
column30: as Amnesia does not give the player access to weapons. The player must then find hiding places or barricade doors with rocks
column32: monsters are capable of tearing down doors in their path and kicking obstacles out of the way
column33: and move extremely fast once they have spotted their prey.\nMonsters who lose sight of the player will search for them for a time
column34: but will eventually leave and vanish.Players can also choose to hide in the shadows
column36:
since the main character ironically enough suffers from Nyctophobia (severe fear of the dark).

Story:
In late August 1839
column39: awakens in the dark halls of the Prussian Brennenburg Castle with little to no memory about himself or his past.\nAll he can remember is his name
column40: that he lives in Mayfair and that something is hunting him. Shortly after awakening
column41: Daniel discovers a note written to himself
column42: from which he learns that he has deliberately erased his own memory
column43: and that he needs to descend into the Inner Sanctum of the castle. There he must kill the baron
column44: a man named Alexander.\nThe exploration of the dark depths of the castle (following a trail of pink liquid that he seems to have left for himself) is also a journey into his own erased past
column45: as he discovers not only notes and his own journal entries
column46: but experiences visions of past events that took place within the castle's countless chambers - including memories that are not his own.\nWhile Daniel unravels the mysteries of Brennenburg Castle
column47: he also finds himself hunted by a dangerous unearthly presence that manifests itself as a corruption that is slowly covering the castle in fleshy
column48: acidic growths.\nAs if this was not enough
column49: baron Alexander has sent out his minions to find Daniel - bizarre
column50: zombie-like monsters that are relentlessly hunting him.\nDaniel's only hope is to as quickly as possible reach the Sanctum
column51:
before he succumbs to either the monstrosities or his own damaged mind...

My opinions:

I was first introduced to this game a couple of years ago
column52:
by a classmate who had downloaded it.
He was passing the time by playing it on a break in school and I was watching.
At the time I didn't think much of it and had not yet been introduced properly to the genre of horror-games.
What I do remember
column54: is that Amnesia: The Dark Descent was scary to play even whilst sitting in a fully lit room.\nMy friend - who was a bit of a coward - even hightened the gamma setting in the game
column55: making it lighter (something I would not recommend unless you're a cheater). But even though he had hightened the lighting
column56: we still got scared off our arses when the first jump-scares started to show up.\nBesides "Outlast" - which is another brilliant game available here on Steam - Amnesia: The Dark Descent remains in my top five of all horror-games I have ever played. Sure
column57: it was developed with a much smaller budget and by an indie-studio
column58: but that doesn't make it any less of a horrifying experience.\n\nI don't really have that much more to say about this game
column59: except these simple guidelines:\n1. Buy it and download it.\n2. Play at night

reviewText: When a game has the power to evoke an emotional reaction, other than frustrion and dissapointment, then said game deserves to be considered a success and that is just the case with Amnesia as it's hauntingly gothic dungeons, goulish enemies and bone-chillingly primordial sound design work to instill a sense fear and helplesness. Set in the 19th century Amnesia finds you journeying into the darkest recesses of a medieval castle without the aid of a firearm and punishes your character's very mind, making it difficult to navigate, if you stray a little too far from the light.

reviewText: A fascinating little game.  At its absolute best, it delivers an exceedingly unsettling experience; at some point, you'll almost certainly find yourself cowering in a dark corner hoping desperately that something doesn't kill you and balancing the warm comfort of a candle against the risk something will come around the corner and rip your face off.  At its worst, it's a slow puzzler with sometimes-illogical requirements.\n\nStill, as a short, play-it-in-two-solid-sittings game, it's hard to top the  feel it delivers.  Well worth the 6-8 hours it'll take to finish.

reviewText: Amnesia is easily the scariest game I've ever played, and I'm a big fan of horror games. Games like Resident Evil are a lot of fun, but barely manage to scare me. Also, what's up with Slender being like the standard for a good horror game. Slender is scary once, the first time you see Slenderman. After that you're just wandering through the woods while the same guy chases you. It's good for a free horror game, yet some people think it's the scariest game ever, but it doesn't come close to Amnesia. Anyway, Amnesia scares you in so many ways. Not only are the enemies chasing you incredibly disturbing, there are lots of kind of less obvious, but incredibly scary, moments. Once I went into a room, saw a cage with a dead body in it hanging from the ceiling, and later when I returned to the room it was gone... The story is also very creepy if you pay attention to the notes you find. If you don't use an online guide, like me, the game will take you somewhere from 8-10 hours, but if you do use a guide then it shouldn't take longer than 5 or so. I actually liked their previous games, The Penumbra series, better than Amnesia in terms of gameplay, but Amnesia is much scarier.

I'm not going to give this game a rating because frankly, that would be missing the point.

Amnesia is a game, that is also not a game. It's a grand story meant to be immersed in. It creates a decent immersion of psychological horror in tandem with an impressive artistic display. This is not something for people to brave through
recommended: and brag about". It even tells you in the opening screens. I see a lot of hate coming down on this game as well as praise. And I just see a sea of people who missed the point.\n\nFor those who liked it and missed the point
hoursPlayed: I suppose as long as you had fun I can't really argue. But at the same time you are singing the wrong praises. "Scariest game ever" is not what I would use to describe this.\n\nFor those who disliked it and missed the point
voteText: I see a lot of "I didn't even beat it" comments followed or preceded by "it wasn't even that scary". Once again I will refer you to the opening scene where it blatantly tells you it is not meant to be played to complete. And you also can't really be upset about buying it because even the description reads "A game about immersion
helpfulPercent: discovery and living through a nightmare".\n\nThose who DID get the point

reviewText: Everything that needs be said about this game has already been said. It is a fantastically frightening experience for those that get immersed in horror games and even after countless imitators, it still stands out as the best example of its particular style. Cracks may begin to show in the mechanics if you play it like a regular game, and it requires a certain commitment of mind and focus to have the intended effect, but for those into this kind of thing, it will always be one of the scariest games ever made.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Rejuvenating survival horror. Perfect, endlessly unsettling sound design. Horrifying environments. Pure chilling Lovecraftian narrative told and unearthed in a consistently engaging manner. Puzzles that are simple enough to not become frustrating and challenging enough to not feel like pointless busywork. An unshakeable feeling of being chased and even in the dingiest corners being constantly out in the open and exposed to danger. Hiding from monsters that more often than not aren't there, abusing every inch of your imagination, and when they are there delivering terrifying sequences of frantic escape slamming doors behind you and terrified hiding cowering into walls desperately trying not to be seen, having to balance attempts at avoiding them with your dwindling sanity in the dark. Leaping from box to box in a flooded room avoiding the invisible creature that waits in the water, and the panicked rush to safety when you inevitably slip and hear the splashing rapidly approaching behind you. Lighting, sanity and flight not fight" mechanics that have impacted so much in the five years since its release
date: making it hard to imagine the horror landscape of the 2010s without it. The defining horror game of the decade so far."

reviewText: I will be the first to say that some of the scares in this game are cheap and the programing is pretty predictable at times. Even when you know that sound you heard in one room is nothing, but that corner that is silent is most likely more dangerous, you still get a bit nervous. Honestly, this is probably one of the best and scariest horror games out there. Most people love this game, and it is easy to see why. You will spend most of the gameplay solving puzzles, and half way through the game you will find yourself hiding from monsters a lot. Even so, there are a few curve balls thrown into the game to make it feel fresh. One of my favorite disturbing moments in the game was when I had to try to get away from an invisible water creature by throwing remains acrossed the room hoping that it would go after that instead of me. This game is disturbing, frightening, and chilling, with a great story to boot. Fans of the horror genre will love this game.

I'd say this game is worth for the interesting art design and story if you catch it on-sale like I did. I hesitate to reccomend it at the full $20 because it took me just under 8 hours to complete it once and it wasn't quite as scary as it's reputation made out.

I mean, it was really scary in the opening levels before anything had really happened and the tension was at a high, but once I had been playing long enough that I grew used to the monsters and such it really dropped from horrifying to just creepy.

That being said, there's still enough real scares and an interesting enough story to make te game worth it.

reviewText: Amnesia is one of the first games I played after joining Steam (thank you to the friend who urged me to play) and it drew me into the horror game genre. But Amnesia is still the favorite. The beginning may feel a bit slow to some, but trust me, keep going. This game got my heart beating faster and had me on the edge of my seat often. Turning corners and opening doors become terrifying things. And I'm not scared that easily. This game was a lot of fun for me. I became addicted and played every night until I beat it. The end may or may not disappoint you, but the overall experience should still be well worth the price. And even after you finish there are fan created custom stories to choose from and enjoy.\n\nDefinitely play this game at night, no lights, and with headphones on!

reviewText:
Amnesia has a special something that most games fail to acheive.

That is what you become aware of almost as soon as you finish the game. The only way I could possibly describe the game once I finished was... Wow... Just wow... The game is probobly the example of what a horror game should be for all the indie creators and AAA developers out there. However, what does this game achieve in?

To start off, we must discuss the story. The story is what makes up a game for me as a gamer. Game has bad story, its a bad game. There has only been a handful of games that go against this, but even still, those handful don't match the rest. However, Amnesia's story is phenomenal and a lot darker then you anticipate. When I entered, I thought this game was going to have a very gothic story (which it did) but did not see the grisly scenes of torture coming up on the plot. Even if this is all told in flashbacks and distrubing hallucinations, it does not take away from the fact the story is messed up. YOU WILL REGRET TRYING TO REMEMBER WHAT YOU FORGOT. Daniel says to himself in the very beginning I choose to forget" and you'll see why sure enough. To put it simply
date: do not doubt for a moment this game's story will get to you.\n\nOnto Gameplay

reviewText: I found out about this game through a review in PC Gamer magazine. I'll be the first to admit that I was skeptical about the mechanics (no weapons? what!?) but they are the key to the terror of this game. In any other scary game, you can just whip out a plasma cannon to destroy the things that scare you. In this game, all you can do is cower in fear and hide. This key mechanic, whereby you are rewarded for hiding raises the fear levels unlike anything I have ever played. When you round a corner in some dank, dark castle sub-floor and hear an inhuman growl, I guarantee you will soil your pants. The game itself oozes atmosphere, and it even encourages you to play in the dark with headphones on. This game is absolute ART that will TERRIFY you. I tell people all the time, Amnesia makes Dead Space feel like a walk through a sunny
date: butterfly-filled meadow." There were literally moments where I had to step away from it to gather myself
recommended: it is THAT SCARY. Do yourself a favor and GET THIS GAME!"

reviewText: This is such a fantastic game - even though I'm having problems with it, no matter how many times I die to monsters (or end up getting stuck inside a room) I just want to keep playing. In fact, I'm doing a series of highlights videos on my Youtube channel where I'm playing through this pretty much completely blind. I'm not picking up any notes or journals or diaries; I'm not reading anything, and I'm still having a blast with it when I'm wandering around not knowing what to do. I guess that's just another great thing about this game; they managed to make a coherent story using only flashbacks, so that even without reading any of the important stuff I still kind of know why I'm doing what I'm doing. I'm even looking forward to finishing this first playthrough so I can go back on my own and read everything up, pick up all the details I missed and see how much that changes the story.\n\nThis is the first part of my series if you want to check it out: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Dp4ucw3dOaw

reviewText: Amnesia is easily the scariest game I've ever played, and I'm a big fan of horror games. Games like Resident Evil are a lot of fun, but barely manage to scare me. Also, what's up with Slender being like the standard for a good horror game. Slender is scary once, the first time you see Slenderman. After that you're just wandering through the woods while the same guy chases you. It's good for a free horror game, yet some people think it's the scariest game ever, but it doesn't come close to Amnesia. Anyway, Amnesia scares you in so many ways. Not only are the enemies chasing you incredibly disturbing, there are lots of kind of less obvious, but incredibly scary, moments. Once I went into a room, saw a cage with a dead body in it hanging from the ceiling, and later when I returned to the room it was gone... The story is also very creepy if you pay attention to the notes you find. If you don't use an online guide, like me, the game will take you somewhere from 8-10 hours, but if you do use a guide then it shouldn't take longer than 5 or so. I actually liked their previous games, The Penumbra series, better than Amnesia in terms of gameplay, but Amnesia is much scarier.

reviewText: Amnesia ist ein ganz besonderes Spiel. Bei Amnesia erkundet man aus der Ego-Sicht eine Welt im Traum des Protagonisten, eine riesige Burg mit vielen dunklen und gruseligen Geheimnissen. Das Spielprinzip basiert darauf, dass man unter Druck zum Überleben animiert wird, flüchtet, sich versteckt und versucht den schrecklichen Gestalten zu entgehen, die die verlassen Mauern und Gänge der Burg unsicher machen. Man hat einfach Angst! Dabei findet man keinerlei Waffen oder Gegenstände, mit welchen man sich wehren könnte. Ein völlig neues Spielgefühl entsteht, wenn man panisch vor einem Monster wegläuft, Türen hintersich verschließt, durch welche man ebenfalls verfolgt wird, nur um weiter im Stress das Weite zu suchen und dem Geheimnis dieser Traumwelt auf die Spur zu kommen. Ich hatte selten solche Angst in einem Spiel, wie in Amnesia! TOP!

reviewText: 9/10 Dark atmosphere, great story, amazing look. This game takes reality and destroys it right in front of you. Exploring the maddening tale of Daniel's life as he seeks to destroy a man who is trying to kill him sends chills down the player's spine, whether monsters are near or not. It focuses less of jumpscares and more on atmospheric fear, a much more effective fear tactic, especially when the player can't fight back. There are a few glitches, but the gameplay and storyline is amazing. Get this game, it's worth every cent.

reviewText:
If you enjoyed the Penumbra games, you'll enjoy Amnesia. It's as simple as that. The graphics are a bit better, though. Frictional improved their engine a fair bit in the meantime. However, one thing I don't like about this latest title is checkpoints/autosaves. If you want to manually save your game, you can only save and exit. You can't just save and continue on. They force you to quit the game. I take it this was done to discourage constant saving and reloading. But I'm still not pleased with this change.

The conscensus seems to be that Amnesia is possibly the scariest game yet made. I disagree. It is creepy, yes. No doubt about it.

I can't go into further details without spoiling the game, but Amnesia is not as frightening as it's made out to be. I actually prefer the previous Penumbra titles to this one. Amnesia is good, yes. But I felt Penumbra had the better narrative and was a more memorable experience.

reviewText: So. Much. Mystery. Amnesia: The Dark Descent is by no means child's play, and I do not recommend it to the light-hearted. It's thick. Very thick. And the last eigth or so of the campaign is rather morbib. But if you're wanting an edge-of-your-seat game, this nailed it. Of course, I approached it wanting what it had to offer: mystery, thrill, and scare--and it delivered quite well. If you liked the Myst series, Amnesia brings about a whole new depth to venturing the unknown. Quite honestly, I had to buy the sequel the day after I finished it just to suffice my hunger for what The Dark Descent had given me--I can only hope The Machine for Pigs is half as good.

reviewText:
*The* scariest game I've ever played. Play through the whole thing alone in the dark with headphones on, and you're a braver man than I.

This title was the follow up to Frictional's Penumbra series, and continues the same style of play. However, unlike Penumbra where the darkness was your friend, it's an ever-present threat in Amnesia. Staying in the dark for too long will slowly scratch away at your sanity, causing you to see and hear things that aren't there. Insanity causes your character to behave erratically, essentially turning you into walking monster pheromone.

Seeing as lantern oil and tinderboxes are in limited supply, this serves to drive the player forward through the game.

The sound design is really fantastic, the graphics are admirable and the environment and monsters are diabolically nightmarish. The only thing keeping this from being a perfect horror title are some simple gameplay exploits.

reviewText:
This game is a buggy peice of ♥♥♥♥, which randomly crashes upon switching maps, It's easy to randomly clip out of bounds (I managed to on my first playthrough) and items can often get stuck or go through walls. These are just some of the numerous bugs and glitches found in this game.

The options menu is kinda good and it runs decent on bad computers. But one problem is that the gamma settings are for the entire system which means that if you have 2 monitors and put the gamma on the highest setting, the other monitor will look terrible.

But the bugs aside this is about the best survival horror game you can find as I'm typing this. The first person view and making you not be able to fight back make this game really tense and scary if you are in a situation where the monster spots you and you must run. The environment, ambience and of course the soundtrack is mostly what makes the game scary. It's not actually the monster itself that is so scary, it's the premonition of him being around every corner you see that makes the game scary.

Overall i would recommend this game to people that liked Outlast because of the similarities and also to people that just enjoy being scared.

reviewText: What can be said about Amnesia that hasn't already been said? Rather than attempt to quantify what makes Amnesia one of the most popular horror games to date, I'll just say that if you're looking for scares that are actually scary, look no further.\n\nAmnesia is a horror game with inventory puzzles and an odd little sanity mechanic I like to call hide and go soil yourself". While my experience with other horror games has been limited
date: I can say without a doubt that Amnesia may provide one of the most visceral experiences you have ever gone through in a video game.\n\nAmnesia is an absolute joy to play with your friends. If you can manage the time
recommended: play through it once on your own
hoursPlayed: then invite your friends to play it watch them experience it for the first time. Amnesia is the only game that I have found able to inspire such a feeling of well-meaning spite towards your friends. The kind of spite where you want them to go through the same horrors you did just to see who has better bladder control.\n\nWhen you're done with Amnesia
voteText: and you've plumbed the depths of any of the interesting custom levels made by the community
